metadata.title: Effect of Si-modified zirconia on the properties of MoO<ce:inf loc=post>3</ce:inf>/Si-ZrO<ce:inf loc=post>2</ce:inf> catalysts for sulfur-resistant CO methanation

Effect of Si-modified zirconia on the properties of MoO3/Si-ZrO2 catalysts for sulfur-resistant CO methanation Jia Gu a Zhong Xin a b ⁎ Miao Tao a Yuhao Lv a Wenli Gao a Qian Si a a Shanghai Key Laboratory of Multiphase Materials Chemical Engineering, Shanghai, People’s Republic of China Shanghai Key Laboratory of Multiphase Materials Chemical Engineering Shanghai People’s Republic of China b State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering, School of Chemical Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, Shanghai, People’s Republic of China State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering School of Chemical Engineering East China University of Science and Technology Shanghai People’s Republic of China ⁎ Corresponding author at: No.130 Meilong Road, Xuhui District, Shanghai, People’s Republic of China. No.130 Meilong Road Xuhui District Shanghai People’s Republic of China Graphical abstract Catalysts prepared by Si-modified zirconia possess more active species and more Brönsted acid sites, which can improve CO conversion and CH4 selectivity. A series of Si-modified ZrO2 supports were prepared by incorporating different content of silicon and loaded 25 wt.% MoO3 for sulfur-resistant CO methanation reaction. The prepared catalysts were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), N2 physisorption measurements, infrared spectra of adsorbed pyridine (Py-IR) and hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR). The results demonstrated that Si-modified ZrO2 achieved more stable ZrO2 phase, more oxygen vacancies, larger specific surface area and more Brønsted acid sites. Catalysts prepared by modified ZrO2 exhibited smaller metal particles and different interaction between metal and support, which possessed higher activity with 63.4% CO conversion and 59% CH4 selectivity than unmodified catalyst at 550 °C under 2.5 MPa with 100 ppm H2S. Keywords Sulfur-resistant methanation Mo-based catalyst Modified zirconia Doping silicon Incorporation 1 Introduction In recent decades, energy crisis and environment pollution issues are concerned by public. Hence, the continuous development of fossil fuels has attracted increasing attention, especially the efficient and clean utilization of coal. Synthetic natural gas (SNG) produced by syngas is an extremely reasonable way to convert coal resource and the key step is CO methanation reaction [1]. Generally, Ni-based catalyst is intensely attractive for its excellent catalytic performance and relatively low cost [2,3]. However, it is limited by the rigorous conditions of high H2/CO ratio (more than 3) and low sulfur content (less than 0.1 ppm) [4]. Therefore, the removal of sulfur species and adjusting H2/CO ratio are necessary for Ni-based catalysts to react efficiently. It has been reported that Mo-based catalysts could stand not only the low H2/CO ratio, but also the high sulfur concentration in feed gas [5]. Hence, Mo-based catalysts have been studied widely for their outstanding performance of water-gas-shift and sulfur resistance, which eliminate the need of the adjustment process of syngas [6–8]. Various oxides such as Al2O3 [6,9], CeO2 [10], ZrO2 [11], SiO2 [12] and composite oxides such as Al2O3-CeO2 [7,13], CeO2-ZrO2 [14], Al2O3-ZrO2 [15],SiO2-Al2O3 [12] have been applied to the Mo-based catalysts. Myoung Yeob Kim et al. [12] have reported that ZrO2-loaded Mo catalysts have faster CH4 generation rate than other commercial supports, for instance, γ-Al2O3, SiO2, SiO2-Al2O3, ZrO2, YSZ, CeO2 and TiO2. Meanwhile, ZrO2 possesses superior redox ability, high thermal stability, acid-base properties and strong interaction with metal [16]. Consequently, ZrO2 is a favorable support as sulfur-resistant CO methanation catalysts to load molybdenum. Although pure ZrO2 exhibits these advantages as a catalyst support, it tends to possess a low specific surface area [17], single acid sites (Lewis acid) [18] and limited oxygen defects [19]. To enhance the specific surface area, the incorporation of Y [20], Cu [21] and Si [22–25] into ZrO2 have been reported and the effect is remarkable. Ca [19,26], Sm [19], K [27], Si [18,23,24,28] and Mg [27,29,30] are also effective modifiers to change the acid-base properties of supports. Additionally, the amount of oxygen vacancies of ZrO2 can be increased by doping Ca [26], Ce [22] and La [22]. Interestingly, the incorporation of Si can not only form Si-O-Zr structure to enhance the specific surface area but also lead to an undercoordination of surface oxygen to induce the Brønsted acid sites [18,24,28]. The large specific surface area is helpful to disperse active species and the Brønsted acid sites promote the cleavage of C–O bonds and hydrogenation [28,31]. Consequently, incorporation of silicon into ZrO2 is a promising treatment to improve the dispersion of active species and promote the hydrogenation to enhance the CH4 selectivity for sulfur-resistant CO methanation catalysts. Few cases have reported that Si-modified ZrO2 supported molybdenum as catalysts were employed in sulfur-resistant CO methanation. In this paper, the effect of Si incorporation on the physicochemical properties of Si-modified zirconia supports was studied and the catalytic performance of MoO3/Si-ZrO2 for sulfur-resistant CO methanation reaction was tested. All samples were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 physisorption measurements, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and infrared spectra of adsorbed pyridine (Py-IR). 2 Experimental Zirconyl chloride octahydrate (ZrOCl2·8H2O, ≥98%), ammonium hydroxide solution (NH4OH, 25–28%), anhydrous ethanol (CH3CH2OH, ≥99.7%) and ammonium molybdate (VI) tetrahydrate ((NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O, ≥99.0%) were purchased from Titan Scientific Corporation (Shanghai, China). Ethyl silicate (TEOS, (C2H5)4SiO4) was purchased from Lingfeng Chemical Reagent Corporation (Shanghai, China). All reagents were used without purification. 2.1 Support preparation The silicon modified ZrO2 supports were prepared with a precipitation method using ammonia solution as precipitation agent and TEOS and zirconium oxychloride as precursors. ZrOCl2·8H2O was dissolved in deionized water thoroughly and then the solution was added into the dilute aqueous ammonia (pH = 10) dropwise. During the adding process, ammonia was also added slowly to maintain the pH of mixed solution around 10. Subsequently, the white mix solution was stirred for 1 h at 35 °C before adding a certain amount of TEOS into the mix solution (molar ratio: Si/Zr = 0, 0.02, 0.04, 0.06, 0.08, 0.10). After stirring for another 1 h, the precipitate was separated by filtering and washing with deionized water. Afterwards, the white precipitate was suspended in diluted aqueous ammonia (pH = 10), and then transferred to a Teflon round bottom flask, aging with stirring for 12 h at 90 °C. Then, the products were filtered and washed thoroughly followed by drying at 105 ℃ for 12 h and calcinating at 550 °C for 5 h with ramp of 1 °C /min. The obtained white solid was named as xSi-ZrO2, where x was denoted the hundredfold molar ratio of Si/Zr. In other words, if x was 2, it meant that the molar ratio of Si/Zr was 0.02. On the contrary, when x was 0, ZrO2 without silicon was used as a reference. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The xSi-ZrO2 supports were ground to powders (<150 mesh). Incipient-wetness impregnation method was applied to prepare the Mo/xSi-ZrO2 catalysts using ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate as molybdenum precursor. The mass fraction of MoO3 in catalysts was 25 wt%. Usually, the impregnation process took 10 h and then the catalysts dried at 60 °C for 12 h and calcined at 550 °C for 5 h with ramp of 1 °C/min. 2.3 Catalyst characterization XRD was applied to detect the crystalline properties of xSi-ZrO2 supports and Mo/xSi-ZrO2 catalysts. The XRD instrument was Bruker, D8A A25X with Cu radiation at 3 kW and the wide angle scan ranges were 10–80 ° with a step increment of 0.02°. The average sizes of MoO3 crystal were calculated by the Scherrer equation at the diffraction peak of 27.3°. The volume fraction of tetragonal ZrO2 (νt) and monoclinic ZrO2 (νm) were estimated by Eqs. (2–4) in Supplementary information according to literature [32]. XPS was performed using the instrument (ESCALAB 210Xi, Al Kα radiation; hν = 1486.6 eV) to detect the chemical and valence state of Mo, O, S and Zr elements. The binding energy of XPS data was calibrated of C1 s at 284.6 eV. The specific surface area of xSi-ZrO2 supports was analyzed with a N2 adsorption-desorption analyzer (Micromeritics, ASAP 2000). The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method was applied to calculate the specific surface area and the samples were degassed at 300 °C for 3 h prior to the analysis. Images of TEM were collected using a high-resolution transmission electron microscope (JEOL-2010). The samples were ultrasonic treated in ethanol and then dispersed on a microscopy carbon-supported grid before the characterization. Py-IR analysis was conducted on a thermo Nicolet 6700 FT-IR spectroscopy to characterize the acid properties of xSi-ZrO2 supports. Prior to analysis, the xSi-ZrO2 supports were pretreated at 300 °C for 2 h under vacuum and then cooled down to room temperature to collect a background spectrum. Following the injection of pyridine, the sample cell was saturated for 30 min and then evacuated for 30 min at 150 °C under vacuum. Finally, the spectrum was collected at room temperature. From the results of Py-IR, quantitative analysis of Lewis and Brønsted acid densities were calculated by the Eqs. (5–6) in Supplementary information according to literature [33]. The H2-TPR profiles were obtained using micromeritics Auto Chem II analyzer to record the reduction properties of prepared catalysts. Prior to analysis, the samples were pretreated at 200 °C for 1 h in Ar atmosphere to remove impurities and then cooled down to room temperature. Subsequently, the samples were heated to 900 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min in a gas mixture of 10 vol% H2/Ar. The catalytic performance of Mo/xSi-ZrO2 catalysts for sulfur-resistant CO methanation was evaluated in a continuous flow fix-bed tubular (d = 10 mm) reactor. Prior to perform each test, 1 g catalyst was sandwiched by quartz sands in the middle of the reactor and then sulfurized in situ in a continuous flow of 5 vol% H2S/H2 at 400 °C for 4 h. Subsequently, the evaluation of methanation activity was carried out at following conditions: feed gas composition was 2H2: 2CO: 1N2 (molar ratio), containing 100 ppm of H2S; the weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) was 6000 ml/(g·h); reaction temperature and pressure were 550 °C and 2.5 MPa respectively. The concentration of H2S was chosen to be 100 ppm since the alcohol washed and hydrodesulfurized raw gas from coal only contains little H2S (0–100 ppm) being fine desulfurized. Afterwards, products were quantitatively analyzed by online GC (Techcomp, GC 7890) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector, a flame ionization detector and a reformer, after the gas was cooled down to room temperature. The conversion of CO and selectivity of alkane, alkene and CO2 were calculated using Eqs. (7–9) in Supplementary information. Every catalyst was repeated for three times and taken the average to ensure the data reproducibility and accuracy. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of supports To analyze the change of Zr 3d binding energy, the results were summarized in Fig. 1 and Table 1 . It can be clearly seen that signals corresponding to ZrO2 (Zr4+) and Zr(OH)x(Zr3+) are observed in the Zr 3d5/2 spectrum at 182.2 and 183.7 eV for the ZrO2 without modified, respectively [34,35]. With the increasing of Si/Zr molar ratio, the binding energy of ZrO2 (Zr4+) and Zr(OH)x (Zr3+) gradually shifts towards higher binding energy, up to 182.8 and 184.1 eV respectively. This can be due to the formation of Si-O-Zr structure. Since the electronegativity of Si (1.90) is stronger than that of Zr (1.33), electrons around Zr would easily transfer towards Si atoms, which causes the decreasing of Zr electron cloud density and results in the increasing of Zr 3d5/2 binding energy. [24,36]. In brief, the silicon is incorporated into ZrO2 and forms Si-O-Zr structure. From Fig. 2 , all O 1s peaks can be deconvoluted at 532.2 and 530.8 eV denoted as OI and OII, which corresponding to the defect oxygen and lattice oxygen respectively [14,33]. To quantitatively calculate the relative content of defect oxygen in supports, the spectra was split to two peaks and the results were presented in Table 1. With the increasing of silicon modifier content, the proportion of defect oxygen in xSi-ZrO2 supports increases from 33.5% to 52.4% gradually, which means incorporation of Si into ZrO2 can increase the amount of oxygen vacancy on the surface of supports. The increase amount of surface defects can strengthen the interaction between metal and support [37]. The powder wide angle XRD technique was used to study the effects of Si incorporation on ZrO2 phases and the results were pictured in Fig. 3 (a). The diffraction peaks at 2θ = 24.0°, 28.2°, 31.5°, 34.1° and 2θ = 30.2°, 35.2°, 50.6°, 60.0° are corresponding to the monoclinic (JCPDS No. 78-1807) and tetragonal (JCPDS No. 81-1544) phases of ZrO2 respectively. The characteristic peaks of SiO2 (2θ = 20.9°, 26.3°, 36.5°, JCPDS No. 46-1045) are not found in all samples. Combining with results from the Zr 3d XPS, it indicates that the doped silicon forms Si-O-Zr structure with ZrO2 rather than SiO2. Obviously, ZrO2 without doping silicon exists mainly in the form of monoclinic phase. Once silicon is doped into ZrO2, the volume fraction of tetragonal phase increased significantly and the results in Table 2 also demonstrate it. The volume fraction of tetragonal phase increases with the increasing of Si/Zr molar ratio up to 6Si-ZrO2. When the molar ratio of Si/Zr is more than 0.06, the supports are pure tetragonal phase. Additionally, N2 adsorption-desorption analysis was performed to investigate the specific surface area of xSi-ZrO2 supports. As shown in Fig. 3(b) and Table 2, with the increasing of silicon content, the specific surface area of supports increases from 60 m2/g to 192 m2/g. All these phenomena are according to the formation of Si-O-Zr structure after doping silicon into ZrO2. The Si-O-Zr structure can improve the stability of tetragonal ZrO2 phase [23,38], suppress the transformation from tetragonal to monoclinic [39] and inhibit the shrinking and sintering of supports during calcination [18]. Fig. 4 showed pyridine-adsorbed infrared spectra of xSi-ZrO2 supports in the range of 1400–1575 cm−1. Generally, the band around 1547 cm−1 [28] is assigned to Brønsted acid sites-bonded pyridine (BAS), the signals of Lewis acid sites-bonded pyridine (LAS) are detected at 1444 cm−1 [33] and addition band around 1495 cm−1 [28] is ascribed to the vibration of pyridine on Lewis and Brønsted acid sites. The densities of acid sites were calculated based on the integrated absorbance values of the bands at 1547 and 1444 cm−1 and the results were shown in Table 2. The ZrO2 support without doping silicon only exhibits the Lewis acidic sites bands, indicating that the original pure ZrO2 is Lewis acidic. However, as the Si/Zr molar ratio increasing, the Brønsted acid sites begin to appear and the quantity increases to 13.4 μmol/g gradually. The quantity of total acid sites and the relative fraction of BAS increase with the increasing of silicon content. As proposed by Foratita et al. [28], the coordination number (CN) of Zr in ZrO2 is eight, whereas the CN of Si in SiO2 is four. The incorporation of silicon into ZrO2 structure and thus the formation of Si-O-Zr lead to an undercoordination of surface oxygen for ZrO2 rich samples. Hence, a proton is needed to balance the undercoordination of oxygen and then produce the Brønsted acid sites. Therefore, with increasing silicon content, more oxygen is undercoordinated, more protons are needed and more Brønsted acid sites are induced ultimately. 3.2 Characterization of catalysts The XRD patterns of the Mo/xSi-ZrO2 catalysts were shown in Fig. 5 . All catalysts reveal the diffraction peaks at 2θ = 12.8°, 23.3°, 25.7°, 27.3° and 33.8° assign to MoO3 crystal (JCPDS No. 89-7112). The average size of MoO3 crystallite was calculated by Scherrer’s equation at 27.3° due to its highest intensity and the results were listed in Table 3 . The crystallite size of MoO3 on unmodified ZrO2 is 96.4 nm, and with increasing the Si/Zr molar ratio, the average size of MoO3 decreases to 51.1 nm gradually. This demonstrates that the enhanced specific surface area resulting from silicon doping improves the dispersion of MoO3 particles. Since the active species of catalysts are MoS2, the MoO3 should be transferred to MoS2 before the sulfur-resistant methanation reaction. The H2-TPR characterization was applied to determine the ease of reducibility of molybdenum to study the ease of sulfurization of molybdenum. As shown in Fig. 6 , the curve is divided into two regions: the middle-low temperature zone of 200–550 °C and the high temperature zone of 600–900 °C. The middle-low temperature zone is attributed to Mo6+ reduced to Mo4+, which consists of Mo6+ in Zr(MoO4)2 and MoO3 reducing at 300 °C and 350–550 °C, respectively [40]. Generally, the peak in the range of 400–450 °C is the major peak. The high temperature zone is attributed to Mo4+ reduce to Mo, which consists of Mo4+ reduced from Zr(MoO4)2 and MoO3 reducing to Mo at around 700 °C and 800 °C, respectively [16]. From the trend of curve, the reduce temperature of major peak lowers firstly and then raises. When the Si/Zr molar ratio is 0.04, the reduce temperature is lowest and the catalyst is easiest to be reduced and sulfurized. The reasons included following two aspects: On the one hand, the interaction between metal and SiO2 is weaker than the interaction between metal and ZrO2 [41,42]. When silicon is doped into ZrO2, part of Zr atoms in the surface is replaced by Si atoms. As a result, the interaction between metal and support is weakened compared to pure ZrO2 and the higher the silicon content, the weaker the interaction [43–45] and finally MoO3 can be reduced easier. On the other hand, smaller particles are easy to interact with vacancies and special sites in the surface to strengthen the metal and support interaction and then raise the reduce temperature [34,37,46–48]. Therefore, with the increasing of Si/Zr molar ratio, the amount of oxygen vacancy in the surface increases (Table 1) and the size of MoO3 particles decreases (Table 3), which leading to strengthen the interaction between MoO3 and support and become difficult to be reduced. Under the combination of these two aspects, the reduce temperature of MoO3 lowers firstly and then raises. When the Si/Zr molar ratio is 0.04, the catalyst is easiest to be reduced and sulfurized. The Mo 3d XPS characterization was performed to confirm the relative content of sulfurized active species. In Mo 3d spectra (Fig. 7 ), three types of Mo 3d5/2 peaks can be observed at ca. 233.1 eV, 231.2 eV and 229.0 eV and the Mo 3d3/2 peaks are located at 236.0 eV, 234.1 eV and 232.0 eV [49,50]. The peaks at 232.0 eV and 229.0 eV are ascribed as disulfide MoS2 (Mo4+). The peaks of intermediate molybdenum oxysulfide species (Mo5+) are located at 231.2 eV and 234.1 eV. Additionally, there are Mo oxides (Mo6+) for the appearance of peaks at 236.0 eV and 233.1 eV. To confirm the results from H2-TPR and calculate the amount of active species, the XPS curves were split and every area ratio was calculated (Table 3). The relative content of MoS2 increases from 82.7% to 85.6% firstly and then decreases to 75.1% with increasing of doping silicon content. Connecting with the results from H2-TPR, the trend is consistent and the catalyst with 0.04 Si/Zr molar ratio is easiest to be sulfurized and contains the most active species. This indicates that incorporation of Si into ZrO2 could change the interaction between metal and support to impact the reducibility of catalysts and ultimately the Mo/4Si-ZrO2 catalyst has the most active species. HRTEM was applied to observe the morphology and dispersion of MoS2 species and the length of MoS2 was evaluated with measuring the chord length of approximately 300 different MoS2 slabs. As shown in Fig. 8 , with the increasing of Si/Zr molar ratio, the length of MoS2 decreases from 9.03 nm to 7.55 nm and distribution becomes narrow. The results match with the decrease of MoO3 crystal size (Table 3), which indicates incorporation of silicon can enhance the specific surface area and then improve the dispersion of metal particles. However, too much silicon would decrease the reducibility of catalysts (Fig. 6) and then decrease the relative content of MoS2 species (Table 3). As a result, the amounts of MoS2 slabs in TEM images increase firstly and the decrease. The catalytic performances of all Mo/xSi-ZrO2 catalysts were tested and the results were shown in Fig. 9 . Before the data points were collected, the reaction was stable for two hours under the reaction condition. Afterwards, take the average of five data points collected in 5 h. It can be found that the CO conversion increases firstly and then decreases as the doping silicon content increased. When the Si/Zr molar ratio is 0.04, the CO conversion is the highest and reached 63.4%. In addition, with increasing of Si/Zr molar ratio, the selectivity of CH4 increases from 45% to 59%; CO2 selectivity decreases from 53% to 40%; the selectivity of C2H6 keeps at 1–2% constantly. Additionally, a stability test was conducted at the same reaction condition and the evaluation results were presented in the Fig. 10 . Obviously, during the five hours, all the catalysts have the same stability because the CO conversion and CH4 selectivity stay constantly. Incorporation of Si into ZrO2 can weaken the metal and support interaction, increase the amount of oxygen vacancies and refine metal particles. However, smaller metal particles interact stronger with supports with more defects. Above two factors resulted in the volcano trend of the sulfurization capacity. Combining with the results of Mo 3d XPS (Table 3), the trend of CO conversion matches with the trend of MoS2 relative content. It indicates that MoS2 is the active species and the catalyst with 0.04 Si/Zr molar ratio exhibits the highest CO conversion due to the most active species. For Mo-based sulfur-resistant methanation, reaction over Mo-based catalysts can be considered as the combination of two reactions: (1) CO+3H2→CH4+H2O; (2) CO+H2O→CO2+H2, which occurred separately [51]. As proposed by literatures [52–55], the trace of CO can inhibit the hydrogenation of CO2 and then the possibility of CO2 hydrogenation is excluded here. Therefore, the reasons of CH4 selectivity increased are caused by following two aspects. For one thing, incorporation of Si into ZrO2 enhances the specific surface area, improves the dispersion of MoO3 and refines the MoO3 particles. As proposed by literatures, WGS reaction (reaction (2)) is easier to occur on bigger particles [4,56]. In other words, refined particles inhibit WGS reaction, reduce the CO2 products and then enhance the selectivity of CH4 relatively. For another, ZrO2 modified by silicon possesses Brønsted acid sites and the protons from Brønsted acid sites promote the cleavage of C–O bonds and hydrogenation [28,31]. Therefore, incorporation of Si can promote reaction (1) CO+3H2→CH4+H2O and enhance the selectivity of CH4. 4 Conclusion A series of investigations on physicochemical properties of xSi-ZrO2 supports and catalytic performance of Mo/xSi-ZrO2 catalysts had been carried out. The CO conversion of modified catalysts Mo/xSi-ZrO2 approached 63.4% when Si/Zr molar ratio was 0.04, and the CH4 selectivity of modified catalysts Mo/xSi-ZrO2 approached 59% when Si/Zr molar ratio was 0.08, while the CO conversion and CH4 selectivity of unmodified catalyst Mo/ZrO2 were 58.9% and 45% respectively. The characterization results demonstrated that incorporation of Si into ZrO2 can maintain the stability of ZrO2 phase, increase the amount of oxygen vacancies, enhance the specific surface area of supports and induce Brønsted acid sites. Catalysts prepared with modified ZrO2 possessed smaller MoO3 particles, different interaction between metal and support and dispersion of MoS2. Proper content of silicon (Si/Zr = 0.04) incorporated into ZrO2 weaken the interaction between metal and support most and the most amount of MoS2 was generated by sulfurization, which resulted in the highest CO conversion. Additionally, the refined active metal particles and induced Brønsted acid sites could inhibit the production of CO2 and promote the hydrogenation of CO, which improved the selectivity of CH4. Consequently, catalysts prepared by Si-modified ZrO2 exhibited excellent activity of sulfur-resistant CO methanation. Acknowledgments This research was financially supported by the National Natural Science Funds of China (Grant numbers U1203293, 21776091 and 21808062), Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities (22A1817025), the program of Shanghai Subject Chief scientist (Grant number 10Xd1401500), China Postdoctoral Science Foundation (2017M611474), and the Program of Shanghai Leading Talents (2013). coredata.dc:description: A series of Si-modified ZrO2 supports were prepared by incorporating different content of silicon and loaded 25 wt.% MoO3 for sulfur-resistant CO methanation reaction. The prepared catalysts were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), N2 physisorption measurements, infrared spectra of adsorbed pyridine (Py-IR) and hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR). The results demonstrated that Si-modified ZrO2 achieved more stable ZrO2 phase, more oxygen vacancies, larger specific surface area and more Brønsted acid sites. Catalysts prepared by modified ZrO2 exhibited smaller metal particles and different interaction between metal and support, which possessed higher activity with 63.4% CO conversion and 59% CH4 selectivity than unmodified catalyst at 550 °C under 2.5 MPa with 100 ppm H2S.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of Si-modified zirconia on the properties of MoO3/Si-ZrO2 catalysts for sulfur-resistant CO methanation
